title-group.article-title: Benign Ganglion Cells “Invasion” in Prostate Needle Biopsy

article-meta.aff: 1Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Policlinico of Modena, Modena, Italy
2Azienda Arcispedale St Maria Nuova, Reggio Emilia, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Giulio Rossi, MD, Section of Pathologic Anatomy, Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Policlinico, Via del Pozzo, 71-41100 Modena, Italy Email: rossi.giulio@policlinico.mo.it

body.p: In the prostatic region ganglion cells are generally found in periprostatic soft tissue, but Sakamoto et al1 evidenced their presence in the fibrous prostatic capsule (capsular ganglia) in 22 out of 42 (53%) radical prostatectomy performed for prostatic adenocarcinoma. In addition, Yorukoglu et al2 evidenced ganglion cells in the capsule in 22% and in the prostatic parenchyma in 12 out of 64 (18.75%) radical prostatectomies. In spite of these data, clearly demonstrating that ganglion cells may exist in the prostatic tissue, the finding of prostate glands infiltrating ganglion cells is generally considered diagnostic not only of malignancy but also of extracapsular extension, even in needle biopsy.3,4 We report herein a case denying both beliefs.

A 66-year-old patient with prostate enlargement and a total serum 5.4 ng/mL of prostatic-specific antigen (PSA) level (free/total PSA ratio = 45%) underwent prostatic needle biopsy procedure (12 samples; 6 each per lobe). The prostatic tissue showed hyperplastic glands with mild chronic inflammation. One out of 12 samples (biopsy at posterior peripheral right lobe) showed benign hyperplastic glands “invading” ganglion cells (Figure 1A and B). The positive staining for p63+CK903 (Figure 1C) along the basal lining confirmed the benign nature of the glands, whereas S-100 (Figure 1D) highlighted the ganglion cells.

caption.p: Benign-looking prostatic glands surrounded by ganglion cells in needle biopsy (A and B). Immunostaining with p63+CK903 (C) and S-100 (D) highlights a basal cell lining and neural gangliar structure, respectively

body.p: Although perineural infiltration by benign prostate glands is an unusual but well-described phenomenon,4 to the best of our knowledge this is the first case reporting ganglion cells infiltration by nonneoplastic prostatic epithelium. It is important for the pathologist to be aware of this pitfall in prostatic needle biopsies: when in doubt, a few immunostains may be adequate in further ruling out malignancy. Moreover, this case highlights that defining extracapsular invasion in needle biopsy based just on the presence of ganglion cells infiltration may lead to an erroneous evaluation of tumor stage, with potentially deleterious consequences on patient’s management.
